title: Does a thing exist, if we don't have a name for it? - Quora

response.answer_text: Ah, Does a thing exist if we don’t have a name for it? Quite wierdly, there are many solutions to this because, unfortunately, the question s actually not specific enough. Now, here are the three ways I interpreted your question: Does a physical thing that hasn’t been discovered yet exist if we haven’t assigned it an identifying name? Yes, it does physically exist, it just is not able to be understood through thought, just like wave compressions of when a tree falls in the forest, the sound exists, but it is never interpreted into the proper sound by a human.Does a thing exist if we are not able to interact with it and put a relativistic understanding on it? Depending on which great philosopher you look to, the majority will say no. Descartes would say you cannot be sure it exists and people who study relativistic understanding would also say no, due to the not being able to interact with the thing to put a definition on it.Does something, that does not have any matter or thought pertaining to it physically or metaphysically, have an identifier by which we can understand said, thing? If this was your question, than the answer is no. It goes back to the whole question of existence. Their can be something that exists (finite and existing), something that does not exist (finite and non existing, but still can possibly exist if the correct combination happens), never not existing (infinite and existing, think the Catholic God) and finally the never existing (infinite and non existent, this idea or thing shall never exist no matter how many combinations of time space shall exist, not physically or metaphysically). The thing with no identifier falls into the last category.Now, hope you find this information useful and good luck on finding your answer. It is questions like these that make me realize that we take for granted the fact that we can just accept existence.

We can still theorize about some things that don’t have names yet. For example, if there is an unknown element in the Periodic Table it can be given a number. Scientists often have reasons to guess about new elements, based on the properties that have been observed in nature, and the number of possible protons and electrons, etc. If there is no evidence that can be used to predict whether something can exist or not, then it becomes hard to think about, and is often considered unreal. Humans can sometimes use multiple types of evidence to predict that something as complex as evolution or planetary rotation, for example, occur. Many things are covered by large categories like ‘the imaginary’, ‘the physical’, ‘the scientific’, and traditions like philosophy. Science fiction writers sometimes write about what categories like these would look like to an alien species. Many of the categories end up looking imaginary and absurd, and also hard to think about. However, so far as sophisticated human creations like logic or novels, in some way you’re right, because unless we already know its name and some of what the name means, it is unlikely to have any relevance to us. As humans, we try to take advantage of the available tools, rather than things that are deemed distant, incomprehensible, or imaginary. Some of the limits on imagination are simply norms of language and intelligence, and the sophistication of science and philosophy, or other categories. Sometimes there may even be an entire discipline that we would consider imaginary, that on another planet would be considered hard science. It may depend on our assumptions, and the types of abilities people have, including their mental powers and physical powers (or some other power).

Great question! There are some who believe that the world as we know it is entirely, or almost entirely, of our own making. In a universe that consists of continua (fields) and nothing else, in which everything is connected, everything is one, it can be accurately said that any thing (apart from the thing that is the universe or, if you prefer, the Tao) exists only in our mental acknowledgement of the thing. It has further been said (eg by G. Spencer-Brown) that the act of naming something creates an artificial distinction, separating the part of the universe to which the name applies from the rest to which the name does not apply. Names create things that aren't otherwise there. I differ from that opinion only a little. There was a time in my life before I knew any words. Yet I made distinctions and saw things. I began to manipulate my environment before I had learned any words. Probably I formed mental symbols by which I identified things. Probably the earliest form of each symbol was its appearance, or taste. Perhaps over time each symbol evolved into an amalgam of associations, which eventually included words. I do think that our minds have a huge influence on the appearance of the world. But I think it would be too simple to blame it all on language.

I take your question literally: if you mention the possibility of giving a name to this thing, you already have the start of a representation for it. A considerable percentage of our mental representations have no name. Take, for example, the reflex of blinking under the effect of bright light. This reflex exists, is owner, and yet, by default, is not named by you. There, suddenly, you may be tempted to call it "My-reflex-of-blink-in-full-light," but beforehand it led its little fellow way of reflex without possessing any name. And it is the case of an immense majority of our mental representations, whatever they correspond to real things or abstractions. The name is above all a medium of communication. It is necessary to share the existence of things, not to create it. This sharing reinforces the presence of the thing with the name. Mental / environmental exchanges are always bi-directional. However the thing exists in your mind before being named, and if you are a wild child or live alone you do not really need to baptize your concepts so that they are acting.

Existence is not determined by language. Language does not determine existence. An example of this is the concept of untranslatable words. What has a name in one language may not have a name in another. The English language has one name for “snow” while some Inuit dialects have over twenty different names for it showing that this phenomenon is important to their culture. This does not mean that more types of snow exist where they live but reflects the variations of snow that the observing culture notices. “Mokita” is a word in the Kivila language spoken on the Papua New Guinean island of Kiriwina. Loosely translated it means “the truth we all know but agree not to talk about”. In English we don’t have a name for this but we still know or are aware it still exists. For example one might say “let’s not talk about the elephant in the room”. Another abstract concept which exists across the whole humanity but which doesn’t have a name in most languages is that feeling when you exchange a meaningful look with another person who you want to kiss but you’re both worried about being rebuffed. This exchanged look is called “Mamihlapinatapei” by the Yagán people of Tierra del Fuego. While these are abstract and not concrete examples the underlying argument stands that language does not create that which it describes. For more examples of words which the English language has no name for see: Untranslatable Words

Yes, things exist even if we don’t name them (actual world). No, things cannot exists if we don’t name them (model world). This third view is controversial because of many different studies that have been done in the area of Cognitive Linguistics. Things might not exists for us (in our mind) if we have no word for them. For example, if a community does not have a word for God, the concept of God is completely absent in their understanding of things that exist. Things might exists for us (in our mind) even if we have no word for them. For example, numbers. We don’t need to name numbers to have the concept of two things.

Q. Does a thing exist, if we don't have a name for it? Short answer: (1) Yes (2) In the beginning, nothing had names. As things were progressively discovered, revealed, found, peeled, names were assigned. If things didn’t exist if they had no names, explorers would not have discovered uninhabited new lands;chemists, new elements;Isaac Newton, gravity.(3) And perversely, we give names to things which don’t exist. So, the correlation between name and existence is tenuous.

It is really difficult to answer your question. Of course our galaxy existed before we found out that galaxies were a thing. But on the other hand, in the subjective experience of anyone who does/did not know about galaxies, there was no concept of what a galaxy was. But the thing goes even deeper! Yes, because you could say that we cannot really see galaxies, but the concept apparently holds even for the most obvious things. There is a recent article that argue that, since there was no word for “blue” until recent times, people did not “see” the color blue: Homer (author of the Odyssey) describes the color of the sea as “wine-dark”… if you think about it, that does not really express the concept of blue, so people did not even have a concept for blue. (No one could see the colour blue until modern times) Or, again, there are languages where there is no word for left or right, so these people use east and west to describe directions. Does Your Language Shape How You Think?

Yes. Yes it does. If you bought a dog, and didn't name your dog, would it still exist? “But we already call them dogs!” OK! Let's say you found the first dog ever. Before we even started calling them dogs. Let's say you didn't name it, ever. Would it exist? Yes, yes it would. In fact, if they didn't exist, we wouldn't be able to name them in the first place. Because there would be nothing to name! It wouldn't exist! NOTHING would exist if they initially required humans to name them before existing, not even humans.

You can’t say that it exists, and you can’t say that it does not exist either. How can you possibly, if it never crossed your mind yet? But once it does, you have a name for it, even if it is not a word. A memorized mental image is a name too, of sorts. The thing itself does not say “I exist”. You do. And you assign borders, deciding where this “thing” ends and the next one starts. Outside your mind there are no “borders” and no individual constant unchanging “things”. Those are byproducts of a particular way of thinking that we use. Something exists. But not what you might think, and only momentarily. It is called “experience”.

Q: What was the highest mountain before Mount Everest was discovered? A: Mount Everest. Things exist long before they are discovered. Human consciousness does not create physical matter; it does acknowledge it. Linguistic determinism is a school of thought that holds the philosophy that human language and inherent brain structures that produce thought limit what can be imagined (i.e, if we can’t produce the words, we can’t imagine something that does not yet exist. But this does not apply to physical reality. Physical reality does not need to be imagined; it exists. Craig Rusbult, Ph.D. writes in Quantum Common Sense (using Quantum Physics) about Schrodinger's Cat: Scientific Quantum Principles, and Nonscientific Interpretations in New Age “Mystical Physics” : Regarding Schrodinger’s Cat, “What we know about the cat does not determine what the cat is, and the sequence of events that determines "what the cat is" (dead or alive) occurs quickly and irreversibly due to quantum decoherence.” (Emphasis in the original text.) In other words, Schrodinger’s cat is alive or dead the moment the life ending event happens, or doesn’t happen, regardless of when the cat is observed next. Or to put it simply (using Ayn Rand’s maxim, “existence exists.”

The question cannot be answered in an effective or meaningful way. A “thing” can exist, if there is no name for it. But in order to argue the existence of a thing, it needs to be referred to as a specific identity that exists. Identities require definition, even if the identity is not entirely known or understood. Identities which exist, do so at least in some knowledge context. Even a  fictional identity can be referred to as something that exists in a fictional context.  A character in a fictional book for example, can be indicated as an identity that exists as the character in a fiction.

Sure it does. It did before we discover and give it a name. Its existence is precisely the reason we give names in the first place. The mind cannot be the reference for nature’s existence as it can either dismiss facts in nature or create illusions from the supernatural. The mind is a parasite and it perishes as the brain cools down.

Certainly. If I were deaf, mute, and blind my brain would still recognise objects by touch, taste, and smell. A 1 year old child cannot speak but can navigate well squirming around in the floor. Everything that we know own that exists could be described somehow. If it didn't exist it wouldn't have a name.

Early humans had no language but we had temporal existence all around. As languages started coming up, new words were coined for items that were easily seen and felt. EXISTENCE OF THINGS DOES NOT NEED A NAME TO BE GIVEN. However, new types and chains of viruses and bacteria do sometimes appear according to researchers and they name and label them……. That is altogether a different scenario. Thanks for asking, Pete.

A name does not dictate the existence of something. Our unawareness for a thing and its existence does not mean it doesn't exist, rather we simply do not know of it. It's unawareness of something that makes it nonexistent for an individual.

Undiscovered things remain unnamed until in the domain of perception’s range, excepting those mean meme arrangements, idea derrangements, and poetic-license fictoid myth-range dissidents named proceeding practical cross-your-path instances of Incident. -(poem self-evidently by me, only cited to prevent autobot moderation strike for non-citation of my own work!!!)

If it exists, it exists with or without being named by humans.If it does not exist, it does not exist with or without being named by humans. The exceptions are new names, which can be made up new, and new inventions, which can be invented new.

Things exist but until we put a name to them and define their boundary conditions or attributes they aren't things, they're just patternless stuff. By recognizing that a thing is distinct it becomes distinct for human purposes. Until that happens everything is one for all intents and purposes because we haven't defined any intents or purposes.
If you acknowledge that something exists, then it exists. Names are convenient ways to refer to specific things or ideas. Existence is not dependent on our definitions.
We use names to point to things, to pull them out of the background and bring them into the foreground. If we don’t have a name, we have a hard time pointing.

I have a different opinion than most of the other answers given here. There is no way to know whether things exist even before we see them. Maybe the entire universe is made up by us and it didn’t exist before we see them. So, the answer is maybe yes, maybe not. We don’t know.
Things exist, hence we needed a name for it. Stuff will exist even though you may not name it. Existence is not dependent on you, for defining it.
Yes. Why would “we” have anything to do with the existence of other things?
You must be joking, Mister OP. The universe doesn’t depend upon humans for anything, nonetheless a word!
Yes. In semiotic meaning, semiosis, is only one dimension of objects. So i guess things exists.
well, something, this thing and that thing exist, doesn’t it?
If a tree falls in the woods and there's no one there to hear it, do the squirrels grab their nuts and run?
